awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Knowledge and processing of morphosyntactic variation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines grammatical variation across two different dialects of American English: Mainstream (or "Standard") American English (MAE) and African American Language (AAL). The project compares speakers of both dialects to participants who speak only MAE, using multiple experimental methods to determine what participants know about the grammatical patterns of each dialect and how they use that knowledge to guide moment-to-moment processing of sentences. The results will show when and how listeners with different backgrounds successfully accommodate dialect differences, which can inform efforts to mitigate the difficulty of dialect variation in settings such as schools and courtrooms.

This project tests the hypothesis that people know the grammatical rules of dialects they frequently hear, regardless of whether they produce a given dialect.  In a sentence rating task, participants listen to examples of Mainstream American English and African American Language, then read a series of sentences and rate how likely a speaker of each dialect would be to say each utterance. Items vary in their grammaticality in each dialect, including sentences that are grammatical in both dialects, ungrammatical in both dialects, or grammatical in AAL but not MAE. Second, an eye-tracking task tests how participants use the grammatical rules of a given dialect to guide their moment-to-moment interpretation of a sentence. Stronger effects are predicted for bidialectal participants than for monodialectal participants, since bidialectal participants have more knowledge of each dialect and shift their expectations of grammatical form depending on their interlocutor. This project unites central questions from the fields of psycholinguistics and sociolinguistics, showing how linguistic experience and social knowledge shape both representations of language in the mind and real-time processing of varying grammatical systems.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to investigate how people understand and process grammatical differences between Mainstream American English (MAE) and African American Language (AAL), focusing on subject-verb agreement rules (e.g., "They were happy" vs. "They was happy"). The project sought to determine what people know about these rules in different dialects, how they use this knowledge when processing language in real-time, and how this knowledge and processing differ between those who speak only MAE and those who speak both AAL and MAE.

Two experiments were conducted to explore these questions. The first experiment tested participants' knowledge of grammar rules in MAE and AAL using two tasks: a sentence rating task, where participants rated how likely a given grammar pattern was in each dialect, and a task where they had to interpret ambiguous sentences based on carefully manipulated audio files. The second experiment used eye-tracking technology to observe how participants use their knowledge of grammar differences to interpret sentences in real time. The first experiment showed that all participants had some knowledge of the grammar rules in both MAE and AAL, but those who spoke both dialects had a more detailed understanding of AAL grammar and were more likely to expect AAL patterns, regardless of the speaker's dialect. The second experiment revealed that when listening to an AAL speaker, all participants were more likely to interpret sentences using AAL grammar. Additionally, those who spoke both dialects were more likely to consider AAL interpretations overall, regardless of the speaker's dialect.

This project has significant implications for language research in both psycholinguistics and sociolinguistics. It demonstrates that people have knowledge of different grammars and use this knowledge when processing language in real-time, challenging theories that assume a single, unified grammar. Furthermore, it highlights the important link between language processing and social factors. The methods developed in this project, particularly the sentence rating task, provide a quick and efficient way to group participants based on their experience with different dialects, addressing a major challenge in conducting reproducible research on dialect variation.

The findings also have practical implications for education, as they shed light on what educators and students already know about dialect differences. This knowledge can inform future training and efforts to create more inclusive and equitable educational environments for speakers of minoritized dialects, contributing to the ongoing discussions on how to best support language diversity in schools.
